element_texts.text:
2

Jan- 1st,, 1867
Another year begins today. It is my wish to spend it more to the service of God and to my own improvement than the last one was. The day was spent in writing and other employments and one would not know from anything going on, that it was "Happy New Year". 2nd  The Crows are in a quandary about the Sioux. They have received orders from them to leave our vicinity and they are afraid to disobey, and yet would like to remain and help the whites. 3rd The Colonel is making arrangements with "Iron Bull" and a few other indians to stay as spies and scouts.

3

just like mulattoes.
Jan 7th Two indians went out as scouts this morning and in the afternoon came back accompanied by six or eight Crows who belonged to a party that went from the Crow Village to join the other band. They were on their way to the village, and stopped here over night. The report now is that the Sioux are encamped on the Big Horn near the month and are on their way up. "Lone Horn" "The Roman Nose" Sioux Chiefs were in the Crow Camp a few days before they moved and told the Crows that they were friendly to the whites and are going to leave the other Sioux and would join the Crows next spring and his with them. They told the

Jan 4 The indians raised camp early and moved to the river bank first above the Fort, intending to cross the river in the morning and move over towards Wind River valley. A great many came up to camp as they came by. Jan 5th Indians moved early. "Iron Bull" wouldn't stay, but "Annahare". "The Black Eagle" and three or four others remained. Jan 6th "Shot in the face" a chief of some importance remained behind and this morning moved up to camp and pitched his lodge. Fitted the indians out in uniform of which they are very proud, but I think it spoils their appearance and makes them look

4

appeared to be about 15 degrees on either side of the sun.
There were arcs of four different rainbows in the sky. each having their centers in a different point. The figure they formed was somewhat thus. ( * )
Jan 13th                                                                                                                                                                                                              __   (

   Very stormy. Read some in the bible.

Jan 14th. This was one of the stormiest days I ever saw There was about 6 inches of snow on the ground and a very strong wind blew all day drifting the snow up in some places 15 feet deep. The hospital was completely snowed in. It was impossible to see more than a few feet at any time during the day owing to the stormy snow. The snow is drifted

Crow chiefs to come up and tell the whites to fortify as the Sioux to the number of several thousands would be here in a week or so.
Jan 8th Great preparations have been in progress for some time strengthening the fort, and preparing for a seige. 
Jan 9th Hauled up a lot of ice intending to use it for water in case we are hemmed in.
Jan 10 Snowing again.

"    11 Ditto. The scouts report plenty of buffalo on the road to Phil Kearney, but say they are not moving. If they were moving this way it would be a sign that the mail was coming.

Jan 12  Saw a fine sight this afternoon. It was the phenominon  of the Sun dogs They were very distinct &

5

Jan 17th "Shot in the face" and family left for the Crow village. He said he didn't think the Sioux were coming here at present, but thought they would come in the spring. 
Jan 18th The other indians with the exception of Amishace and one other left for the village.
Jan. 19th Nothing new.

"     20th    "         "
 "     21st   "         "
 "     23rd   Five or six indians came in from down the river: they have been living with the Gros Ventres and are on their way to the Crow Village. They say there are four white traders with the Arapahoes near the mouth of this river. They also said that some Cheyennes were on Tongue River some time ago and saw a great smoke

up higher than the stockade in some places.
Jan 15th The wind fell suddenly last night and this day is comparatively pleasant. I saw a fire mirage down the river this afternoon. Could see the timber along the river for a great distance. Columns would shoot up over the little Horn Hills and suddenly disappear. Some of them would form in the shape of long thin clouds and assume all its fantastic forms imaginable. 
Jan 16th The scouts report hearing a shot and to have seen the buffalo moving down the river. One went out again in the afternoon but didn't see any thing suspicious.

6

Jan 26th I have been rather unwell for a few days, but am better today. Lockwood took my gun out and shot 7 sage hens and some rabbits, so that we had a splendid dinner on rabbit pie and sage hen &c. &c. It has been 59 days since we received a mail. It is getting rather tiresome to be deprived of the mail with such surprising regularity.
Jan 27th I am afraid I spent the day rather unprofitably. Read some in the Bible.
Jan 28th. No mail yet although it is two months today since the last arrival.
Jan 29th I must say it is getting rather too much of the good thing, to be so long deprived of the news from the outside world. A warm wind melted most of the snow last night.

in the direction of Piney Fork. That they went to see what it was and found Fort Phil Kearney in ruins having been burnt and abandoned by all the troops. This taken in connection with the fact that some Crows reported seeing this smoke when they were here throws a shade of possibility into the Sioux story.
Jan 24 The Crows that came in yesterday left for the village.
Jan 25th. The above named came back late at night being unable to cross the mountains on account of the snow. The weather is very cold now. The thermometer ranging from 10 to 20 degrees below zero at night.

7

would be the news. He proved to be John Richard with a party of ten men bring fresh vegetables and butter down for sale. They had been some 30 days on the road and were compelled to cache two wagon on Clarks Fork. They have no news later than Dec 15th, but say a telegram came just before they left saying that they had called for reinforcements at Fort Reno and Laramie. They say a negro has been elected to congress from "The Hub". A man having a charter for a ferry across this River came along: Also one wishing to settle and go into the farming business. 

 Was off of the day and was in the house most of the time. Reas some in the Bible.

Note to the side runs off edge of page

Jan 30. Most of the snow gone and the ground thawed out. Quite a pleasant day. Bridger is very uneasy to hear some news from down below. He says the snow is so deep down there that they cannot travel, yet I think he thinks there may be a possibility of the indian story being true.
Jan. 31st A very fine day and every body looking for the mail.
Feb 1st A small band of buffaloes in sight the first for some time. I think the drums drive them away.
Feby 2nd The garrison was all astir from seeing a party with two wagons coming from the direction of Virginia City. There were many suppositions as to who they were, and what

8

while they (the Crows) were in the Sioux village, two runners came in from Laramie telling them they had better leave this country as the troops were coming after them. That they were acting upon this and were all crossing the Yellowstone.
Some more Crows came from the main Village, including Asniahare's mother, or Aunt. 
Feby 7th Two Sergts of the 18th came in from Phil Kearney on foot, carrying dispatches. They confirm the last of Capts Fetterman & Brown & Lieuts Osimmund and Bingham and some 90 men. There are 11 cos at Phil Kearney troops having been sent from Laramie. Carrington has gone to Fort Casper. Genl. Wessells is in command of the Mountain

Feby 4th 1867. With the Colonel and a party rode up on the mountain. All around us, it is snow, snow, snow. The indians say the ground around the Fort is medicine ground and the snow wont lie on it.
Feby 5th Two young Crows came in from Blackfoots band. They are moving this way and will be here in a day or two. They found Richard's wagons but Blackfoot knew them and would not let them be disturbed. 
Feb 6th Twelve "Mwmasaperrie" came up the river to trade with Smith. Eighteen lodges are camped near the mouth of Little Horn. They say the Sioux last 60 men and 100 horses killed at Fort Philip Kearney. That

9

Feby 9th The mail carried by the two sergts & Mikih Boyer left at unclear.
Feby 10th Read in the Bible.

  "     11  Nothing new.
  "     12  The Mimeasaperries left yesterday taking Amahare with them.
  "     13th Richard left for home on the 9th carrying dispatches for the Governor of Montana.

Feby 14th. Some little Crow indians who were up on the mountain hunting say they saw some indians in the Bad Pass just before dark, but whether they were Crows or not they could not make out.
One of Mr. Bridgers men who is up on the mountain cutting timber saw fresh pony tracks on the mountain.

District which has been reorganized. They have been giving us up as dead and I suppose we are so reported in the States. They had made repeated efforts to communicate with us but had failed. As much as $1600 had been offered but the Sergts volunteered without hope of recompence. An order came announcing the 2nd Batt as the 27th U.S. Inf. and owing to the assignment of officer to the other Battalion Col. Kinney is the senior officer with the Regt Lieut. Counselman goes to the 18th Inf. & Lieut. Brewer comes in his place.
Feby 8th Busy preparing papers to go by the Mail.

10

Feby 19th I think this has been one of the coldest days this winter, although the thermometer registers only some 8° or 10° below. There is a steady N.E. wind blowing which makes it so cold. On man had his nose frozen before I got through inspecting the guards.
Feby 20th Still cold

  "    21st  Ditto. The Crows camped on the other side of the river moved down to Beauvais Creek. 

Feby 22nd  Nothing new.

 "     23rd   It is now two weeks since the couriers left; and the Col. sent word that if they didn't let us hear from them by last Saturday that he would conclude that they had been killed. 

Feby 24th  Read in the Bible.

Feby 15th Eight Crows including "Bad Elk" came in today I presume it was them that the youngsters saw yesterday. They report the Crow village all split up and a good share of it gone to Stinking Fork.  
Feby 16th No news from Boyer This was the day he was to be back if he came in advance of the troops. I suppose he will not come now until they get ready to come. 
Feby 17th Read some in the Bible. In rather a bad humor on account of some things that occurred on guard mount
Feby 18th The few Crow lodges spoken of above came in and camped on the small creek on the other side of the river.

11

with his life by jumping down a precipice.
Feby 26th Three Crows were to have gone down to Phil Kearney today but wanted so many things that it was considered a back out.
Feby 27 The Crow village is coming in and camping all around us.
Feby 28th Mustered for pay
March 1st Crazy Head sent two or three boys to carry dispatches to Phil Kearney. They left about 1 o'clock P.M.
Mch 2nd I made a mistake in saying that the couriers started yesterday they did not get away until today 
March 3rd Most of the indians are leaving the vicinity of the fort & going down the river.

Feby 25th The Col has been talking of sending some Indian couriers down & we have made out copies of our requisitions again. 
Five or six indians came in from the village the other day bringing news of a fight with the Snakes up about the mouth of "Shell River". Some Crows stole 50 or 60 head of horses and were followed by eleven Snakes. The Snakes found a Crow away from camp by himself and (the Crows say, smoked with him and then shot him. They then attacked the village and after drawing out some 12 or 15 Crows drove them back. "Iron Bull" lost his gun bows & arrows and narrowly escaped

12

plenty of buffalo there came back to tell the village. I don't know what ideas they have of running courier.
March 7th Nothing new

  "       8th " "
  "       9th Still very cold. Many of the men getting their fingers noses &c &c frozen while on guard.

Mch 10th "The Medicine Wolf Bow", principal man of the "Minnasaperries" and his brother came up bringing news. A Crow had been at the Sioux village and had been told by them that they were all going to move up here and camp around us and were going to fight the Crows as well. That a white man was there who followed him out of camp and told him not to believe the Sioux for they were afraid

Some Minnasaperries? came in yesterday saying that the Sioux were at the mouth of Tongue River and that they were coming here within 15 days. That they had sent tobacco to the Arappaho wishing them to join them but the latter had refused to receive it. However the Arappahoes had gone up to the mouth of Clarks Fork and killed three white men that were living there in a log house. I don't know who they could have been.
Mch 4th Nothing new
"       5th  "        "
"       6th  It has been very cold for some days back. The boys who went as couriers went over as far as Grass Lodge Creek and finding

yet returned. He says it would be impossible for wagons to come through on account of the deep snow.
Mch 13th Nothing new.
" 14th "The Iron Bull" who has been encamped in the immediate vicinity all the time i.e did not move away with the rest, moved his two lodges down close to the stockade.
Mch 15th Seven longer of Minnasaperries moved up and encamped near the sutters house.
Mch 16th A few more Minnasaperries came in. They had been down at some of the other Crow camps and bring news that some Sioux had been in and had such that they had a small war party out last month

of the Crows and if the Crows and whites would fight together the Sioux couldn't whip them. They told him that he had better leave the village, as they would have killed him if they had seen him coming into the village, but as he got in there before they saw him he might go. That the day he left a war party of 40 left the village to come up here.
Mch 11th Very cold.

 "    12 Thermometer has been below -10° since retreat last night. At daylight it was 25° below. "Crazy Head" and brother came in from his camp on Grass Lodge Creek. Another party have started for Phil Kearney, but none have

19

They bring news that those mail carriers that left in Feb were all killed. Also that the Sioux came upon a train of 6 wagons and 18 men on Tongue River coming this way: that they killed 13 of the men and the other 5 made their escape. They say there are 13 lodges of Sioux in the Pretty Bulls camp about 18 miles below this, and that 8 lodges of Crows have gone to the Sioux: that all the Sioux are moving this way: I think we will have lively times here before long. 
Mch 19th. Nothing new.

 "     20th  Some indians came in from down the river who report that the Sioux are scattered to the four winds of heaven and are starving. Some others came in from

who discovered tracks on the road from here to Phil Kearney, that they followed and came upon Boyers party on Tongue River That the whites started for the mountains leaving their pack mules, that going up the mountain their horses gave out and they took to the pines That as they had thrown away most of their clothing and as a storm was brewing they concluded they would freeze to death so they didn't follow them. So if that is true my mail for three months is all gone up.
Mch 17th Was officer of the day. Read some in the Bible.
Mch 18th Another lodge of Minnasaperries came in.

15

I did of him.
Mach 22nd Two couriers left at 11.30 for Fort Phil Kearney by way of the mountains. They are going up the other side of the river to the mouth of Stinking and then go up The other side of the mountain and will cross over at Phil Kearney.
Mch 23rd The couriers (Burnett & George) came back about 9 P.M. and reported the snow too deep also that on their way back they discovered that they had been tracked by 6 indians. I guess Burnett was afraid.
March 24th - The Colonel is talking of sending some more indians down. A young mexican in Q.M. employ offers to go alone.
March 25th Sent off 5 indians with dispatches. "The Medicine Wolf Bow" reports that the Crows are preparing to join the Sioux.

Crazy Head's camp. They say that the Sioux that came to the Crow camp was "The Roman Nose" that he had thrown the other Sioux away and that they had thrown him away, and they would fight him wherever they found him. He has always been more friendly to the whites than the others have. Among all the stories I believe none of them.
March 21st Some one has been throwing poisoned meat around for the benefit of the dogs in the garrison. My little dog "Tip" was one of the sufferers. I am very sorry to lose him, as he was a fine little fellow and had some good traits in him. He was the favourite of the garrison I didn't think I could ever think so much of a dog as

they saw down there. Mitch, Boyer got through but they lost their horses and all their mail.
Mch 27th Maj Burrows assumed command of the Post and assigned me to the command of D. Co.
Mch 28th Capt Burrows says Lieut. Stearns has resigned.
Mch 29th I think I can notice a difference in the demeanour of the indians since the return of the couriers. They seem to think that there are more white people than they had any idea of.
March 29th Nothing new

  "      30th     "      "
  "      31st Had the required monthly inspection.

April 1st Employed a Mountaineer as "Post Hunter" he went out and killed two elk and a

That they are going to keep on good terms until after the wagons come up and are going to trade all the powder they can for the Sioux and then will move over the mountains and send parties to join the Sioux.
Mch 26th Great excitement came by the arrival of a mail carried by the indians first sent. Recd about 30 private letters. Capt Burrows recd 62. Capt recd his commission as Bat Maj, and the Cols resignation has been accepted. They did not send any personal mail and but a portion of the letters. They at Phil Kearney wanted the indians to remain four days longer and see the troops that would arrive then. They seem to be pretty well impressed with what

of the men beat tom-toms and one performed occasionally on a kind of whistle. Three or four women dressed in yellow dresses stood opposite the musicians & performed a kind of dance if you could call it so when they did not move their feet from the ground. It consisted of a series of rapid curtsies. Some of them held a switch in their hand with which they imitated the growth of the tobacco &c &c others held otter skins and other articles of "medicine". All chanted in a kind of screeching monotonous tone.
Apr. 6th Nothing new.
" 7th was on duty. Read a good deal in the Bible have commenced to read it through.
Apr 8th Had a horse race between one of our horses and an indian pony. The pony came in 2nd best. All were thrown into a state

buffalo and brought the two former and the best parts of the latter.
April 2nd The mail couriers returned from Phil Kearney bringing considerable mail. No more troops have arrived at P.K. and we need not expect reinforcements until the middle of May. Most of the snow has melted off and we may look for visitors any day.
April 3rd Nothing stirring but the wind.
April 4th Very busy with my papers. This has been a very fine day. Most of the snow is of the prairie.
April 5th Witnessed the tobacco dance in one of the lodges camped close to the stockade. The inside of the lodge was lined around with indian men and women. Three

18
from the mouth of Little Horn where they are encamped. They seem to be a much better class of indians. They make some pretence of keeping themselves clean.
April 11th The Long Horse and some other indians came up intending to go down to Phil. Kearney with the Colonel.
April 12th Had a council with the indians and the Major read them the letter from Genl Wessells inviting them down to Phil Kearney. A number of them started about noon. They are not intending to have a council now as they want it held on this river.
April 13th Nothing new.
" 14th "Joe the tailor" had a difficulty with an indian and knocked him down.

of excitement by the appearance of 6 indians with led horses in the bluffs on the other side of the river. The Crows said they were not Crows, and we didn't know what to make of their maneuvres. They proved to be some Crows from Beauvais Fork. Their Camp had lost some horses the night before, by the the Snakes and they were trailing them it seems the Snakes had driven them right down to the river just opposite the Camp of "Bear's Tooth", and had then turned and gone through the Bad Pass.
April 9th The Crows say that those encamped on Beauvais lost some more horses last night.
April 10th Three "Nes Perces and their squaws came up the river

19

come back with their lodges. 
April 16th The indians are still coming in. In the afternoon learn that those persons seen yesterday were Crows moving this way from the Little Horn. 
Apr. 17th Some 30 lodges camped in the immediate vicinity.
Apr 18th Most of the indians move over to Warm Creek.
April 19th, 20th & 21st Nothing new.

"      22nd   The "Long Horse" returned from Fort Phil Kearney bringing a pair of slippers for Lt Counselman but leaving the important papers out at his camp, as he said his horse gave out.

April 23rd Another indian came in bringing a package of mail but no letters for me.
April 24, 25, 26 An indian came in each day bringing a small package of mail each. There are still two packages away

The indian came up for redress, and not geting it from the military proceeded to gather a few young men & take it himself. He cut at Joe with a knife cutting his coat. Joe then fired at him with his gun the ball passing just over his head.
Apr 15th Had a great excitement this evening caused by an indian bringing in word that he saw 400 persons on Grass Lodge Creek, coming this way. He supposed they were Sioux. All the indians moved in close to the fort and we were busy watching them as well as for the Sioux. I was in doubt whether the Crows are not playing a game to get in to have a better chance to beg. The "Nes Perces" went away in a great hurry intending to

20

on the 26th inst. It is them that is now returning.
May 3rd Mitch. Boyer came in about 10. PM last night. All alone had traveled so all way from Phil. K. No mail had arrived at P.K. since Mch 5th Rumor of 300 men being killed in Fort at Mouth of Yellowstone.
May 4th Nothing new. Boyer talked with a Sioux in a Crow camp on his way up. The Sioux told him that the Sioux were collecting on Powder River to dance the "Sun Dance" after which they would come here.
May 5th Boyer is to go to Gallatin Valley tomorrow to send flour down.
May 6th Mr. Richard, accompanied by three men came in about daylight. They had come to the river at 2 a.m. The left Gallatin Valley 6 days ago. Mr. R comes as agt for Mr. Croon about supplying the posts with flour.

but they say that the indians who have them have gone hunting.
April 27 & 28th Nothing new.

 "     29th   The Bear in the water brought up a package that one thought contained the official and officers mail, but it only contained some copies of "Casey's Tactics". 

April 30th Mustered unclear
Mar 1st "The dog that bats his eye" brought in the package said to be the last one containing a few papers.
May 2nd Some Nes Perces came in stating that they left the mail party and Mitch Boyer and another white man on Tongue River and that they would be in today. A mail party of Three of Iron Bulls men went down to Phil Kearney

21

flowers in, in front of my house, but the bears and dogs seem determined to tear it up. The former think it a gay place to play in
May 10th Are preparing a mail and thought of sending it today but did not.
May 11th Started a large mail in charge of "The Iron Bull" and one young man. Just as they were starting it commenced raining and continued all day, blowing violently all the time. I  never saw such a disagreeable lonesome day. The mail carriers came back, as the mail was getting wet.
May 12th The mail started again, as the weather has cleared up nicely.
May 13th Lieut C. and the mounted men have been away all day up in the mountains

Mr. C. and Mr. Bozeman started down some time ago, but these five Blackfeet boys came to them pretending to be Crows and after shaking hands shot Mr. B. and wounded Mr. C. The latter fought them three hours when they left him and he made his way home swimming the Yellowstone with his gun straped on his back. These Blackfeet live with the Crows and are now encamped within 15 miles of here.
May 7th Mr. R. , Boyer and another man started back about 3 P.M. Mr. R. says he will be back in 16 days with a train of eight wagons.
May 8th Are issuing corn to the troops as rations. They seem to like it pretty well.
Mar 9th Witnessed a fine buffalo chase on the other side of the river. Made a bed to put

on the other side of the river.
May 16th The Col. took all the citizens strikers cooks &c and went up on the mountain and brought down the log that the Lt had cut for the flag staff. Two crows came in from the village. They say they know nothing of there being Arapahoes over on the road.
May 17th The camp was all astir just after daylight from seeing 6 men coming down the road from Phil Kearney. All supposed they were bringing a mail. They proved to be deserters from Ble 18th, the same ones that Genl W? sent us word about. They left P.K. on the 1st inst. and had been wandering around since, stoping 3 days in the Crow Camp. Soon 6 more came from

getting out a flag staff.
May 14th The Col took some men and went up in the Canon with the boat. They went up some 4 or 5 miles and came back in the evening. They could not find any timber that they could get. Killed a mountain sheep and brought it in.
May 15th A woman came in yesterday from the Bear's Tooth camp and says there were some young men started to come in here and were charged on by a large war party of Arrapahoes, who are on their way to watch the road between this and Virginia City. She says they took everything the boys had except their horses. She thinks that they had been hanging around the fort for several days as she saw horse tracks all over the prairie

23

the 27th will stay on this line.
May 22nd Nothing new
May 23rd Three more deserters surrendered themselves up. They are from G"leo"? 18th and said two others came as far as Tongue River and then turned back. 
May 24th Colonel and a party went up the river again in the boat, on an exploring expedition
May 25th The exploring party returned about noon completely tired out.
May 26th I had scarcely turned over the guard this morning when the cry of "injuns" was raised and 6 or 8 came dashing across the prairie from the Creek west of the fort. They passed within two hundred yds of the stockade, and passing down ran off Leighton's herd of mules and Shane's & the indians' horses. The herds were

the same place, making up the full number of twelve.
18th Nothing new.
May 19th Rained all last night and this morning it is snowing.
" 20th Continues to rain and snow.
" 21st Cleared up during the day
"The Iron Bull" came back before sundown with a small snail? and some blanks. No tobacco. New is that Col Smith is on his way with recruits and Genl Augur is coming out with some 2000 men. Genl  Mes?? is retired at his own request, but is coming up here as soon as Col. Smith arrives with 4 cos of the 18th and one co of the 27th the latter to remain here and the others to return to PK. to be ready to go against the indians. It is probable that

the Crows who went out and talked with them say there were about 60 and a large party on Warm Creek of some 300 or 400. The "Wolf Bow" went out to try and get his horses back, but did not succeed. He started in the afternoon with 5 others saying they were going to steal others from their camps, but they are going to the village to beg them back.
May 27th, 28th, 29th & 30th nothing new.
May 31st Were inspected by the Post Commander.
June 1st Raised the flag staff.
" 2nd The Stars and Stripes were unfurled to the breeze today for the first time. The "Long Horse" and a number of Crows and "Nes Perces" came in to trade.
No sign of Richard yet.

not more than 200 yds from the fort, but before any soldiers could get out they were gone. I think Mr Leighton and two or three men that were in his house at the time could have saved them had they ran out and fired at the indians but they were so much taken by surprise that they didn't know what to do.
The mounted men followed them to the creek on the south east, but indians came running in from all sides and everything had the appearance of a general attack on the fort so they were recalled. Had they crossed the creek, I have no doubt most of them would have been killed. I counted 40 indians at one time but

25

be in tomorrow about 10 a.m.
June 11th  The train arrived on time. They consist of 2 companies of 2nd Cav. Cmd. by Col. Green. 3 Companies of 18th Inf. Cmd by Captain Ogden and one company of the 24th Inf. (E). The latter remains here. Captain McCleery is along. They return tomorrow. Brought 7 wagons with Cav & 2 M supplies, and two wagons with Sutler supplies. A great carnival is being held by the men in tobacco and flour. 

   Col. Kinney & Bridges and Dr Matthewes intend returning with them.

June 12th The escort returned early this morning. Sent a Lieut back with the information that one of

Teuksbury killed a mountain sheep and brought in the horns for me.
June 3rd Nothing new

  "  4th do  do
  "  5th do  do
  "  6th  The "Yellow Face" and some others came in bringing news that the "Swan" had been sent from Phil Kearney to bring the Crows down there to see the Commissioner. They also say that there is a pack train on the way to this place. That it left P.K. on the 4th. Can't believe the pack part of the story.

June 7th Nothing new

 "   8th      do       do
 "   9th No signs of the train
 "  10th Al. Leighton rode in about 8 P.M bringing news that he left the train camped on "Warm Creek; and that they will

26

about 150 bushels potatoes & purchased the flour, beans salt & pepper.
June 17th Richard started about 6 P.M. for Phil Kearney alone. Expects to get in about 10 am tomorrow
June 18th The militia and Richards train left this morning. It seems they have received authority to raise 800 militia. Every one seems to be trying to see how much he can make off the government in fitting them out. 
June 19th, 20th 21st 22nd 23rd & 24th Nothing new.
June 25th About 4 P.M. twelve indians came down the river bank and passing the pickets came over graveyard hill and ran off the mule herd, which was grazing between there and the fort. The mules ran

The cavalry had deserted. Caught him about 3 P.M. About noon Mitch Boyers came in saying he had left Richard on Clarks' Fork and that he would be in day after tomorrow. 
June 13th nothing new
June 14th Richard came in. He is escorted by a company of Mountain Militia. They are a hard set, and although they have a Colonel, a Capt and two Lts, they dont mind any of them, but do just about as they please. The Major did not allow any of them to come on this side the river.
June 15th & 16th Rained.

   "   16th Richard crossed his supplies over including

27
with 20 mounted men and after chasing them 15 miles their horses gave out and they had to return.
The mules shouldn't have been out, without the mounted men being along, as a guard. This is first cause; and then the unfortunate circumstances that I have spoken of above are others. 
The Crows were ordered away immediately.
June 26th Nothing new
" 27th  "  "
" 28th No word of Richard yet. "The Black Foot" came in today and says those four Blackfeet boys who killed Bozeman are still in the Crow camp.

for the fort but they are said to have been headed off by some Crows, who were around, and who ran out whooping and yelling. They then ran around the south side of the fort all the time trying to get to the stables, but when they were within 100 yds of the Sutters some one was unfortunate to fire at the indians who had by this time left the herd. This shot frightened the mules away and three indians whirled and ran around them and away they went for good. 39 mules and one horse belonging to the government and 3 private horses were their spoils.
Lieut Counselman followed

march, having neither food nor arms.
July 5th Nothing new.
" 6th Richard returned to Crow camp.
" 7th Some Crows cam in singing and firing off their guns about 10 P.M. I thought they were Crows until they came close to the stockade when they fired a gun the ball passing over us. We then fired on them, thinking they were Sioux. Had all the men out lying along the stockade.
July 8th Eight or ten Crows came in this morning and said it was them that came up last night. They say/ the came near being killed by our firing. They have been after Snake horses, and say they killed an Arapahoe, who belonged to a party that they met.
July 9th & 10th nothing new.
" 11th About 40 Crows came in from Crazy Head's camp. Richard, Raphael and a miner came along. They were afraid to stay any longer lest the

June 29th & 30th Nothing new.
July 1st Nineteen indians came out of the creek west of the fort about an hour after daylight and charged across south of the fort. I ran out and got two or three shots at them at long range, at the same time 10 more appeared on the bluffs to the S.E.
July 2nd Nothing new
" 3rd Richard cam in. He has been employed by the U.S to stay in the Crow camp and watch their movements. The Crows have been to Phil Kearney and received some presents.
July 4th I wonder when I will spend a 4th at Home, I have not done so for 5 years. One of our prisoners - a deserter made his escape this morning through the carelessness of the Corp. I sent some men out but they could not find him. Went out about 10am and had the good fortune to find him. He was poorly provided for a

The camp is only a few miles distant. It is something strange.
July 15th Quite a number of Crows under Long Horse came in. They are very busy trading for tobacco and seem to be hiding something that they should tell. Towards evening "The Swan" called Richard aside and told him that the Crows were telling lies and hiding the truth. That there were 600 Sioux warriors in the Crow camp under Red Cloud Roman Nose &c: that they the Sioux were camped on the Little Horn. and numbered some 300 lodges: that they were going to send about 3000 or 4000 warriors to fight us within a few days. that they had sent a party to prevent reinforcements from coming up and expected to kill us all before they could push through, that he ran a risk of getting a floging and

Sioux jump them and kill them. They report that the Sioux are only about 40 miles from here: that they say they are coming in force to fight us, before any more troops can come up. The latter they say are near Fort Phil Kearney.
July 12th Richard received the contract for putting up hay.
the indians left and numbers of young men are crossing from the camps on the other side of the river and going to Crazy Head's camp, as they expect the Sioux to attack them or run off their horses and they want to be as strong as possible.
The miner who came in left us as mail courier at dark.
July 13th Indians Crows passing back and forward.
July 14th Not an indian to be seen although it was a lovely day &

the Sioux and join them to fight the whites,. I am not afraid of all the Sioux, but I fear the Crows, as they know so much of our Post.
July 19th Nothing new.
" 20th Mich Boyer and a man named Parker came in about 9P.M from Phil Kearney they left the train under Lieut Col & Bat Brig Genl Bradley at Goose Creek. He had unclear with him, but Mich's dispatches caused Genl Smith to send Major Gordon's company of cavalry to come with them.
July 21st No Crows came in today
" 22nd Genl Bradley said he would be here today, but I don't look for him until tomorrow or next day.
July 28rd The train came in sight about noon, and all got in before dark.

of having his horses all killed by telling these things such a law having been adopted by the Dog soldiers.
16th The Crows all left this morning. At dark sent Boyer down as courier to Phil Kearney. Mr Jim Leighton accompanied him of his own accord. They expect to get through tomorrow forenoon sometime.
17th The Iron Bull and White Mouth came in this afternoon. They give no satisfaction in public, but in private conversation the former confirms the story of "The Swan". A cold rain falling all day and night.
18th Cleared up during the forenoon. There is evidently something going on in the Crow Camp, that they are not willing to tell. I am afraid they will get involved with

erted from H.G last night.
30th Nothing new.
31st Very busy all day. Did not go to bed as Maj. Gordon expects to go away with the train about 2 am.
Aug 1st. About noon a large body of indians made their appearance around the hay field, where Lieut. Sternberg had gone as a guard to hay party on the 30th inst. Some of them came up this way and threatened the wood train coming in from the mountains. I ran out and got two or three shots at them with the new gun at long range, which caused them to pause in their mad career. they then all gathered around the hat party who were in a kind of bush corral, and fought them four or five hours, before we learned from a man

There is Capt Hartz, Lieut Fenton, Lieut. McCauley Lieut. Palmer & Lt Sternberg, for this Post besides Gen; B. Alex. Wishert of Washington is a 2nd Lieut. in our Regt. Co. F. but is temporarily attached to the Cavalry Company. I tell you I was glad to see him. I had not seen any one that I know for the past year or more.
24th Very busy.
25th & 26th Ditto. Am to be relieved of duties in Subsistence Department by Lieut. Shirley. He has relieved Lt Counselman of Q. Master's duties.
27th The Genl took the Cavalry and rode down the river several miles.
28th Went the other direction and all are highly pleased with the scenery in the canõn.
29th One Corpl & 5 privates des-

charge, expecting to meet the captain and 2nd Lieut at Phil Kearney, who would bring them back.
Aug 2nd The citizen who was wounded died this afternoon Lieut S & the soldier were buried with military honors this P.M.
Aug 3rd Nothing stirring
Aug 4th The ox train came in sight about breakfast time and got in soon. Lieuts Hallack & Harwood G & D Cos with it - My Co. came back having relieved K. Co. who came from Phil Kearney with it.
Aug 5th The train was unloaded today and expects to start back tomorrow.
Aug 6th Train left at 5 P.M. Lieuts Watson & Palmer and E Company in charge.

who ran the gauntlet, the true state of affairs. Lieut Shirley had gone out about the same time with 20 mounted men but was surrounded and driven back. Maj. Burrows then was sent out with his own company and H Co. & Lt Fenton and one howitzer. He relieved the party, who had been fighting all afternoon and had lost Lieut. S and one man killed, and one Sergt, two privates and one citizen wounded. 19 out of 22 mules had been shot but most of them will recover. They had killed about 25 indians, and took one scalp. No doubt they punished the indians severely as the? rode up very close, and seemed very reckless of life
Lieut Counselman left with the train D. Co. went in his

and started for the hayfield with the wagons. 
Before they arrived about 60 indians charged on the rear wagon and some stragglers causing them to double quick into the corral. They then surrounded them but did not attempt to fight them. Lt F threw a shell among a group of them causing them to scatter very hastily. Some rode up towards the fort and Richard went out and talked with them. They asked him if he was Richard, and wanted him to go out and talk with them. Threw two shells at them and they moved away.
Aug 12th Nothing new.
" 13th Indians charged on the men mowing?morning? but were driven off without any trouble. They then followed the train up toward

Lieut Fenton & 50 men have gone to the hay field, indians made their appearance in the afternoon and burned a good deal of grass.
7th The grass still burning.
8th Richard and two men came, in followed by his train of 6 wagons. They had a fight with 15 indians on the Rosebud and chased them 6 miles until they plunged into a very rocky, dangerous stream and made their escape.
Governor Meagher was drowned while drunk at Fort Benton N.Y.

Gov. Smith has arrived, the militia were encamped on 25 yd. River, and were in a fearful state of demoralization, and were leaving for home every day taking, horses, guns &c with them.

Aug 9th Richard crossed the river and went to the hayfield.
Aug 10th Nothing new.
" 11th "The Black Foot" came in

Aug 23rd Ditto.
" 24th The Genl. Capt Hartz and myself with some mounted men joined by Richard Boyer and McKenzie went across the river at the lower ford for the purpose of looking for hay. As soon as we got on the plateau we saw herds of buffaloes, and made preparations to run them. Ran in among a herd and killed four. Richard, Boyer and McKenzie being the "nimrods". Came back loaded with meat. While fording at the ford just below the fort Sergt Murphy was drowned.
Aug 25th Read some in my bible.
Aug 26th Nothing new.
" 27th The hay party finished cutting hay, and moved up.
Aug 28th The train started for the woods in charge of Maj Burrows. Egan & Corpl Jackson were arrested and confined on a charge of

the Post, but only fired one or two shots.
Aug 14th. Corporal Gorley , Ret's? Lee Johnson & Burk, left a few days ago and went up the river. I guess they found they could not cross the river and saw they were not joined by a number of others that they expected, so came back about 10 P.M.
Aug 15th Nothing new
" 16th " "
" 17th " "
" 18th Read a good deal in the Bible. It is strange that although I have read the bible a great deal yet I can find things in it every day that I had no idea were in it and I then think strange I did not notice them before.
Aug 19th Nothing new.
" 20th " "
" 21st Privates Burns, C. Campbell & Thomas deserted. Cause - too hard work for the pay -
Aug 22nd Nothing new

35
some fine scenery.
Aug 30th Nothing new, except that Jack Steed and Raphael came in about 3 am having left Lieut Watson and a large train last evening on Little Horn. Steed had come from Phil Kearney with dispatches to the effect that all indians were wanted at Fort Laramie during the full moon of this month. Received a few letters by him. They had a fight at Phil. Kearney between about 1000 indians and 30 of a wood party. Lieut James? Jeuness? & 2 men killed and 2 wounded and 3 missing. Five indians left dead on the field.
Aug 31st Muster &c inspection.
Lieut Halleck, Harwood & Shirley and the mounted men rode out and met the train and brought in the mail.
Sept 1st Read in the Bible. Part of the train got in.

intention to desert. Circumstance strong against them but no positive proof. The bear followed the wood party to the timber 7 miles distant and when they came away he could not be found. I am very sorry as he was a great pet.
Aug 29th Jack Steed came at 3 am with dispatches from Phil Kearney, directing the Genl to send word to all indians to go to Laramie in Sept, to hold a treaty,. Started Boyer & Lanie Richard to the Crow Camp and from there to the Sioux. The bear came in about 6 am on a gallop. Seemed to be glad to get back. Went with the Genl. and a few men up on the mountain ten miles. Saw one antelope and

36 
about a doz of the principal Crows with them, and on the 11th the Col talked with them and invited them to attend the treaty at Laramie, but they declined on account of this being too far.
Sept 13th The rest of the train that Maj G. had left on Little Horn, escorted by Bat Col. Switzer & three Cos. of 2nd Cav came in. They have a train of fifty wagons. The cav have been ordered here for the purpose of scouting along the road and securing the safety of the trains. The officers are in addition to those mentioned. Maj. Noyes? Capt Spaulding, & Lieuts Gregg, Cahill & Steele. Rode out & met them and got plenty of the finest plums.
Sept 14th The Q.M & Alex busy unloading stores.

Sept 2nd All the train arrived safely. Lieut Watson had been sent to Fort Reno. with the train he took down. He lost one Corporal between Phil Kearney & Reno.
Sept 3rd 4th 5th 6th Nothing new.
" 7th Maj. B. detailed to go to Phil Kearney. Does not seem to relish it very much.
Sept 8th, train escorted by G. Co. started about 5 am.
Sept 9th 10th & 11th Nothing new.
Sept 12th Was somewhat surprised to see a small train come over the hill from the direction of Phil Kearney. Proved to be Maj. Gordon and his company escorting Dr Matthewes who comes as Special Agent of the Peace Commission. He comes from the grand Com. to treat with the Crows. I forgot to say that Boyer, Babtiste & Louis Richard came back on the 10th bringing

37 
Sept 20th The Iron Bull's wife and another woman came in. They say the camp has been close all the time but that soldiers would not let them come in, and that they had stolen away. They also say that there will be some soldiers in tomorrow.
Sept 21st Some Crows under the "Long Horse" came in: and had a talk with the Dr. He talked so saucy that he was told to keep quiet. He immediately jumped up and left the council, taking all with him.
Sept 22nd The indians left in the afternoon and took Gooley with them.
Sept 23. Hurley & Burk deserted from the picket post at the hay stacks last night taking with them one government horse & mule, and one pony belonging to the indians

Sept 15th Read in the Bible & the "Golden Treasury".
Sept 16th We are planning an excursion to the cãnon to camp out all night. Thousands of buffaloes on the prairies on the other side of the river.
Sept 17th intended to start to the cãnon this morning but the officers of the Cav. thought it was too cold.
Sept 18th The cav. left about noon for Phil Kearney. Major Burrows brought his Comp back from Phil K. arriving last night. Came through in three days & a half. Ten days since he left here.
19th Sept. The weather is pretty cool: had rain on night of the 17th, but we are not having such disagreeable weather as we did this time last year.

Sept 25th Genl B Lieut Harwood, Dr Matthews, a few mounted men and myself went down to the Crow camp. Found them below "unclear creek about 15 miles from the Fort. Most of the village was moving up towards the fort, so that we met them. As I had been in their camps before it was nothing new for me, but there were many things to interest a person. One is surprised at the beauty of some of the children, especially the little boys. They are busy now making new lodges, and have great quantities of plums, and buffalo berries in process of drying. The "Shot int he face invited us into his lodge, and gave us some plums and talked away for a while. After staying about an hour we came back having been away about seven hours.

The General sent Iron Bull and another indian after them and found them on the road to Va City; they coaxed them to go to the Crow camp and then took them prisoners, and brought them in, and left them on the river bank. They took advantage of the circumstance and hid themselves. A vigorous search failed to find them. Hurley came in at taps and Burk next morning. The "Long Horse" brought in Gooley & Bravo of E Co. who were in the camp.
Sept. 24th The Iron Bull was hired at $100 per month to carry a mail twice a month to Phil K. He and his family expect to live here this winter. I am much afraid that from what "Blackfoot" says John Richard has been killed.

39
-tain militia, whose murdering and robbing in the most reckless manner. In a few hours Lieut Fenton, and 36 men with one howitzer were on the way, infantry in wagons.
Sept 30th Battalion Inspection at 6.30 am.
Oct 1st Commenced my Co. Barracks, so far as laying them out are concerned, and also hauled some stone, sand and lime. The indian couriers started with mail for Phil. Kearney at dark last evening.
Oct 2nd Commenced digging the foundation for the barracks. They are to be 30 feet wide which is six feet wider than those of the other companies.
Oct 3rd Laying stone for foundation.
Oct 4th Richard's train came in

Sept 26th The remainder of the Crows moved up, camping near the Post. In the afternoon the Dr had a talk with the principal men, telling them that as he saw a disposition among them to split up into small bands he would advise them to all keep together and cross the river. They seemed in a better humor than they have been for some time.
Sept 27th All the Crows except The Iron Bull & family crossed the river and are heading for Clarks Fork.
Sept 28th Nothing new
" 29th Richard and another man came in about guard mounting. They came for assistance, their train of ten wagons, loaded with vegetables &c &c being threatened with capture by 100 disbanded mon-

40

conclusion that it could not be gotten down until the river would raise.
Oct 8th & 9th Nothing new.

 "  10th About 15 lodges of Crows came in under Bear's Tooth. While mouth & Blackfoot & Crazy Head, 

Oct 11th The Dr had a talk with them and gave them quite a lot of supplies.
Oct 12th Indians still here. Some have agreed to go to Laramie and Dr. M. starts tomorrow with them.
Oct 13th The Dr started about 10 a.m. taking sergt Pendergest and 15 men as escort. A band of 45 Cheyennes & Arapahoes are over the river about 12 miles. supposed to be watching for the horses of the militia who cam down and we camped close to the river.
Lee and Wm Smith deserted at 3 am yesterday but Sergt Twasmegarr and four men after them and got them 10 miles on the way to mon

in all night not having seen any of the militia. 

   I rode across the river in among the bluffs looking for plums but there were but few as the indians had passed that way and had gathered them all up.

Oct 5th Rode out with the General and some others on the Phil Kearney road and found plenty of plums but they were not ripe. Met the mail courier with a large mail for our Post
Oct 6th Read in different of the books sent in my box.
Oct 7th Richard started for the mountains to haul in timber for saw mill. McKenzie and two men came down the river in a boat to see how their timber that they had  thrown in, was coming on. Found it lodged and came with

41

belonging to gov. besides some private property. Two men came in and reported the state of the case. when the Genl sent "E" amd "I" cos out to bring in the train which they did about 1 am. They found the train all in corral the indians having abandoned the wagons as soon as they had taken all they wanted. 
Oct. 17th 18th been windy for past three days ending up with a rain and snow storm during the night 
Oct 19th Pleasant

 "   20th        "      Read in the Bible

Oct 21st Genl. B. Lieuts Luther Harwood Matson & myself Col Smith. Dr Thatcher (who is a new asst Surgeon come to relieve Dr Gusdorff) and enough men to make 14 of a party and Teuksberry as guide

Mr Story & Mr McAdow left for the valley yesterday, having taken contracts for vegetables & chopped wheat. Read in the Bible. and other books
Oct 14th Nothing new.

  "   15th Some Crows came in and bring a report that the Crows had killed a party of 13 Blackfeet, who came to steal horses.

Oct 16th A train of 100 wagons under charge of Bot St Col Smith, and with detachments of the 27th 18th & 4th Inf muster Lieuts Wishert 27th & Luther 18th came in. They left about one half of the train back with 20 men as guard. and about dark that portion was attacked by indians and the two rear wagons captured and plundered. They are evil to have taken 35 sacks of corn and one bundle of shovels

clear stream at the bottom of the cañon. but they did not get a bite.  After resting an hour or so, we started back, and while ascending my horse steped on a slippery rock and lost his footing and was going down when I caught a saplin and pulled him and myself unclear into the path again. Started after two bears (an old one and a cub) when we had reached the top. Harwood chased the old one and headed it off but the bear made for him and as his revolver missed fire he had to retreat. Teuksberry killed the cub. and as his horse got away while he was dressing it he stuck his gun up with his coat on it, and says that will keep the wolves from touching the carcass. Arrived in camp after a ride of nearly 40 miles at 6 p.m.

visited the cañon. We entered by a gulch about 12 miles from the Post. winding down one of the narrowest and steepest paths I ever saw. The scenery was grand. There were about 4 inches of snow on the ground and the dark pine tree tops were covered with it looking very fine. One of the men was leading his horse down when, the horse steped on a stone, which threw him off the path and he rolled about 60 yards down into rivulet at the bottom of the gulch. He was not hurt much. As soon as we got down had lunch & while preparing it Col T Shot a large rattlesnake having 13 rattles and a button on his tail. After lunch the Genl. & the Col. went fishing for trout in a very fine little

43

Oct 25. Lieut Hallick rode out to Warm Creek for the mail but found there was nothing there except a few letters from Phil. Kearney.
Oct 26th The train of 26 wagons* arrived escorted by Sergt Pendergast & 15 men. On Tongue River he saw about 300 Sioux, who were the party on the way to the Snakes. They sent a Crow in to tell the Sergeant to not be afraid but to move along in safety, as they were not going to trouble him.
Oct 27th Train all unloaded and leaves tomorrow, under charge of Lieut Shirley & detail of forty men from different companies. About 8 am. a train is reported on the hill. Get ready to ride out to meet it thinking it is the government train looked for. Have gone

Oct 22 A fine warm day. The train pulled out, taking all the militia with them.
Oct 23rd The "White Forehead" who was sent by Dr Matthews to the Sioux Camp came back and reports: that the Sioux Cheyennes & Arapahoes are camped near the road. That The Red Cloud with 20 lodges is the only one for war. That Charlie Richard had come up from Laramie and taken a great many Sioux down with him. That a war party of Sioux Cheyennes, Arapahoes and Crows had started to war against the Snakes. That "The war this is afraid of his horses says they will not send out any more war parties against the whites until they hear from Laramie. He also reports Sergt. Pendergest near the Post with a train.
Oct 24th nothing new

44

Troops were paid after muster. Had my Co. books inspected by Col. Merrill. He paid me a very good compliment on my business in general. Lieuts Cahill & Steel came up with a drove of cattle for the Commissary.
The Inspectors and Paymaster all pulled out on the Creek (Kinney's Fork) intending to make an early start in the morning.
Nov 1st and 2nd Nothing new. The mountains are covered with snow and there is a little in the valley but it will not remain long.
Nov 3rd I am 26 years old today, if all reports are correct. I begin to feel as if I was getting old. 
Nov 4th The court martial which had adjourned from the 30th unclear of which I am J.A. met today and tried the men.
Nov 5th. Court in session

but a short distance when we meet Col. Merrill, Major Cushing, Major Grimes, Capt Comly & Jim Leighton. These officers belong to Genl Augur's Staff and are on an inspecting tour. They are escorted by two cos of 2nd Cav. under Col Green, Lieut Tranless & Norton are along also Major Clark, the Paymaster. Leighton's goods will be along in about ten days. They have a large mail. The largest ever received at the Post.
Oct 28th Rode down to Camp & received my Pay. Had my Adjutants books inspected.
Oct 29th Nothing new.

  " 30th Col Green and a party rode up on a visit to the canõn.

Oct 31st Inspection & muster in the morning. It was a most disagreeable, dusty windy day.

45 

distant, yet as Genl Smith says, they had not enterprise enough to find out what was going on, but said they thought the indians were killing buffaloes. The Cavalry were sent out and found Lieut S had had quite a battle. That underline he end underline was wounded. Pvt Partenheimer G. Co. Killed. Corpls. Donnelly H. & Fitzgerald I. wounded, the first since dead, and two or three wagons lost. One a U.S wagon with mens' blankets & mail & the other a sutler wagon belonging to Leighton.
Nov 9th The court was not in session today. Maj Gordon is now in charge of the train. Lieut S having been taken back to Phil K. He had a painful wound through the foot, shot clear through with an arrow.
Nov 10th Read in the Bible. Maj Gordon is reported within ten miles of here.

Nov 6th. The weather was so unpleasant that the court could not hold its sessions today.
Nov 7th & 8th The court in session until noon of the 8th. The indian boys came in with a mail. 

  They bring news that Lt MC?? started from Phil Kearney with a obscured train with instructions to exchange with any one he might meet. He was corraled 6 miles from the Fort and kept there until relieved by Genl Smith and sent on. Met Lieut Shirley four miles further on and after exchanging trains returned to the Post. In a day or two Shirley sent them word that he had been attacked. Cols Green & Merrill had just arrived & had heard the firing as they passed the train on the other or new road, and were only a few mls

45

Five of them crossed the river and made for Teuksbury's scratch out? wagons that were over there after hay but 3 or four men went across from this side and they kept at a good distance.
19th Mr Story's train of 28 wagons came in from the valley loaded with potatoes. McAdow's train of 12 wagons will be in tomorrow. They have not been troubled by indians.
20th Mr McAdows train arrived all right about midnight. Story's train crossed the river and commenced unloading.
21st 22nd Nothing new
23rd The mail couriers came back with the news that that Maj. Bust was going to camp on Warm Creek tonight; that he had recruits and about 25 wagons. Maj sent a letter in which he said they were somewhat demoralized. & that he would like to see some

Nov 11th Proceeded with the court.
" 12th Major G. came in with the train.
Nov 13th Finished up the court, having tried 14 cases. Lieut. Belden is along with the train. He is Maj. G's 2nd Lt. Leighton's loss is about $15000.00
Nov 14th Major G. left with the train.
" 15th There are rumors that there are six white men in the Crow camp who are bringing news that Richard, Dr M. & party are at Phil K. on their way back. I don't believe it.
16th Charlie Smith came in with three or four men. They say they heard that Dr M. was on his way back,
17th We have the finest weather.
18th About 40 Sioux charged up from below the Crow camp, which is in the timber below the Post, i.e. 40 lodges under "Thin Belly," and ran around trying to get some stock., but did not succeed..

47

serving at Phil Kearney.
29th Nothing new
30th Inspection although it was very cold
Dec 1st Nothing new

 2nd & 3rd "     "
  4th Lt Matson & Mr Harwood went out a few days ago and killed 7 deer bringing in 6 and going for the 7th next day.
  5th Mail couriers that left on the 2nd arrived at Retreat?. Maj Gordon had gone to relieve a train that had been corraled at Crazy Woman's Fork for three days. The escort had lost 2 killed and four wounded. Capt Harding has been retired on one years pay & allowances; to date Oct 19th but as the rumor is that Lt Stearns has been re instated I may not receive any promotion.

6 7 & 8 Nothing new.
9th A Crow came in from hunting and said a party of Sioux had surrounded

of the old troops.
Nov. 25th Capt Hartz with "I" Co. was sent out to meet the Maj. Met him on the big hill The party consists of Maj B's wife and two children & Miss Reynolds -- Mrs B's sister -- Lt Miller and wife. Dr Frantz -- and 88 recruits that have been culled at Phil Kearney. Their arrival causes quite a stir among the bachelors, as they have to move out of their new quarters.
26th I received 17 recruits in D. Co.
27th Nothing new
28th Snowed about 3 inches last night. Capt Hartz and comp escorts train to Phil K. Lieuts McCaullay and Palmer accompany it having been promoted to 1st Lieuts unclear in Cos

48

P.K. for the presents that the Dr is bringing for the Crows. Smith has located at North Platte and is not coming up here.
14th H Co. under Fenton detailed as escort, Richard talked of starting today but did not get ready. Started the indians for the mail said to be with Dr M. and sent a small mail with them. Maj Burrows has authority to go to Omaha where he will receive 30 days leave. Expects to go with this train. 
15th Nothing new.
16th Train started 7 a.m.
17th   "     returned 11 a.m. Say the snow is too deep.
18th  N. N. 19th mail couriers returned but only a few letters with them
Wishnot is Bot Capt.
20th 21st Nothing new
22 23         Ditto.
24th Sergt Schwarmegar & ten men went out yesterday and soon

him about 4 miles south of the Fort and had threatened to take his horse from him. He had a horse belonging to Charlie Smith & told them they would have to kill him to get it. They struck him over the head inflicting a wound and he says he returned the stroke breaking the stock of his gun. He brought in a horse belonging to an old man who has been living at about this place. Trapping. I am afraid there's some mystery connected with this.
10th Some indians came in who say they are come to take The Iron Bull away with them as he is slightly unwell and they are afraid he will die here
11th The Iron Bull would not go with his friends, but remained here.
12th Nothing new.
13th Richard and a small party rode in from Phil Kearney. R left Dr Matthews & party at Reno & came on to get wagons to go to

49

Newspaper clipping
AGED INDIAN DIES.
FERNANDINA, Fla., (AP)
Death of Jimmy Drummond, 107-year-old Seminole Indian and veteran of the civil war, marked the passing of the last of a hostile tribe of red men that once inhabited Amelia island.

came back with a fine deer 
25th Had quite a fine dinner in the company, consisting of roast venison, soup, vegetables &c &c.
26th Nothing new.
27th Capt Hartz & I. Co. returned from Phil. Kearney. No mail.
28th Sent mail couriers for the mail expected at Phil Kearney.
29th & 30th Nothing new.
31st Troops mustered and inspected by Gener Bradley. Here ends another year. I wonder where and who I will be this time next year
94 pp
[Back cover - appears to be brown leather]
